body:
No. In fact the idea of the compass itself is flawed because it's literally just the left-right axis for economic and social views.

There is a political triangle test that I think represents politics much better, but do note that it's apparently very libertarian biased: https://crystalvulpine.github.io/PoliticalTriangle
body_html:
No. In fact the idea of the compass itself is flawed because it's literally just the left-right axis for economic and social views.

There is a political triangle test that I think represents politics much better, but do note that it's apparently very libertarian biased: https://crystalvulpine.github.io/PoliticalTriangle

body: I don't like trying to split different axis at all. Imo there are a few different "wings" (ideas) about how to organize society, and everything else is just a more granular representation of that.
body_html: I don't like trying to split different axis at all. Imo there are a few different "wings" (ideas) about how to organize society, and everything else is just a more granular representation of that.

body:
The wings are fundamentally order and chaos, The right represents order, the left represents chaos.

However, axis allow for nuance.  Economically, I'm very, very conservative.  In terms of liberty, I'm very much libertarian.  But in terms of society?  I'm contemporary leaning progressive.  This on the axis of:

Authority: Libertarian vs Authoritarian  
Economy: Liberal vs Conservative  
Society: Progressive vs Traditional  

Of course, this is just one possible setup for the axis.  Another I've seen measures freedom instead of order vs chaos, so the arrangement is different.  But this set of axis is the one I understand - and if it's a one dimensional scale, it would suggest I'm centrist.  But anyone who knows me knows I lean right on the mono-axis scale.  It just doesn't provide enough context or detail to get a good idea for who a person is.

It's also a big factor in what led to the political parties, with one representing "left" and one representing "right".  If we had more detail on our politicians instead of just having an R or D, or an L or R, it might help people make more educated decisions than they do now.
body_html:
The wings are fundamentally order and chaos, The right represents order, the left represents chaos.

However, axis allow for nuance. Economically, I'm very, very conservative. In terms of liberty, I'm very much libertarian. But in terms of society? I'm contemporary leaning progressive. This on the axis of:

Authority: Libertarian vs Authoritarian
Economy: Liberal vs Conservative
Society: Progressive vs Traditional

Of course, this is just one possible setup for the axis. Another I've seen measures freedom instead of order vs chaos, so the arrangement is different. But this set of axis is the one I understand - and if it's a one dimensional scale, it would suggest I'm centrist. But anyone who knows me knows I lean right on the mono-axis scale. It just doesn't provide enough context or detail to get a good idea for who a person is.

It's also a big factor in what led to the political parties, with one representing "left" and one representing "right". If we had more detail on our politicians instead of just having an R or D, or an L or R, it might help people make more educated decisions than they do now.

body:
> That quiz seems a little simplistic, honestly. Unless there's something more comprehensive, I figure it's going to misplace many people.

Simple is accurate - in fact the fewer questions needed to measure someone the better. 

The problem I have with most political quizes are:

* Lack of a valid answer (for example should taxes be progressive "yes/no" has no valid answer - its like asking if circles should be triangular)
* Inclusion of non-political questions (It doesnt matter if you like apples or orange, it matters if you would use government to force people to choose the one you like or not)
* Artifical Mirror separation (banning gays is exactly the same as banning straight people - not opposite)
* Lack of context, forcing you to jump to conclusions
* Obfuscation with tons and tons of questions, many of which are minor variations
* Bad economics - if they assume keynesian context the quiz is meaningless


This simple quiz should put most everyone right about where they belong. Do you think there is a major topic area missing?
body_html:
That quiz seems a little simplistic, honestly. Unless there's something more comprehensive, I figure it's going to misplace many people.

Simple is accurate - in fact the fewer questions needed to measure someone the better.

The problem I have with most political quizes are:

  • Lack of a valid answer (for example should taxes be progressive "yes/no" has no valid answer - its like asking if circles should be triangular)
  • Inclusion of non-political questions (It doesnt matter if you like apples or orange, it matters if you would use government to force people to choose the one you like or not)
  • Artifical Mirror separation (banning gays is exactly the same as banning straight people - not opposite)
  • Lack of context, forcing you to jump to conclusions
  • Obfuscation with tons and tons of questions, many of which are minor variations
  • Bad economics - if they assume keynesian context the quiz is meaningless

This simple quiz should put most everyone right about where they belong. Do you think there is a major topic area missing?

body: If you're libertarian that pretty much nullifies whatever your social beliefs are in regards to politics, and probably economic ones too. If you don't believe in government your other beliefs don't matter, as it can't uphold them. That's why I like the triangle where you have the 3 main ideas and the more you are of one, the less you can be of the others: https://crystalvulpine.github.io/PoliticalTriangle/
body_html: If you're libertarian that pretty much nullifies whatever your social beliefs are in regards to politics, and probably economic ones too. If you don't believe in government your other beliefs don't matter, as it can't uphold them. That's why I like the triangle where you have the 3 main ideas and the more you are of one, the less you can be of the others: https://crystalvulpine.github.io/PoliticalTriangle/
